docs.title: Welcome to agrihealth
docs.text:
agrihealth is a Python demo package for sustainable agriculture.

  • Free software: MIT License
  • Documentation: https://terra-geo.github.io/agrihealth

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: agrihealth is a demo Python package designed for farmers, foresters, and environmental researchers to analyze vegetation health and soil moisture using satellite imagery. The package enables offline processing, making it ideal for remote areas with limited internet access.

docs.title: How to install agrihealth
docs.text: pip install agrihealth

docs.title: Vegetation Index Computation
docs.text:
agrihealth allows users to compute key vegetation indices for monitoring plant health and ecosystem conditions:

  • NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index)
  • Evaluates plant health by measuring chlorophyll content.
  • SAVI (Soil-Adjusted Vegetation Index)
  • Adjusts for soil brightness in sparse vegetation areas.
  • EVI (Enhanced Vegetation Index)
  • Enhances vegetation sensitivity by reducing atmospheric effects.
  • SMI (Soil Moisture Index)
  • Estimates soil moisture content to assess water availability for crops.

docs.title: Offline Processing
docs.text:
• Perform all computations locally without needing an internet connection.
  • Ideal for field applications where internet access is limited.

docs.title: Multi-Source Satellite Imagery Support
docs.text:
Compatible with images from:

  • Landsat (NASA/USGS)
  • Sentinel-2 (ESA)
  • MODIS (NASA)
  • Other remote sensing datasets.

docs.title: Easy-to-Use
docs.text:
Simple Python functions to:

  • Load satellite data.
  • Compute vegetation and soil moisture indices.
  • Visualize results with minimal coding effort.

docs.title: Customizable Analysis
docs.text:
Users can fine-tune parameters based on:

  • Different climate conditions.
  • Soil types.
  • Vegetation structures.

docs.title: Visualization & Data Export
docs.text:
Generate heatmaps and overlay indices on satellite images. Export results in multiple formats:

  • GeoTIFF for GIS applications.
  • PNG for quick visualization.
  • CSV for further statistical analysis.

docs.title: common module
docs.text: The common module contains common functions and classes used by the other modules.

docs.title: hello_world()
docs.text:
Prints "Hello World!" to the console.

Source code in agrihealth/common.py 
def hello_world():
    """Prints "Hello World!" to the console.
    """
    print("Hello World!")

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.

You can contribute in many ways:

docs.title: Report Bugs
docs.text:
Report bugs at https://github.com/terra-geo/agrihealth/issues.

If you are reporting a bug, please include:

  • Your operating system name and version.
  • Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
  • Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

docs.title: Fix Bugs
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with bug and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Implement Features
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with enhancement and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Write Documentation
docs.text: agrihealth could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official agrihealth docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such.

docs.title: Submit Feedback
docs.text:
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/terra-geo/agrihealth/issues.

If you are proposing a feature:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
  • Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)

docs.title: Get Started!
docs.text:
Ready to contribute? Here's how to set up agrihealth for local development.

  1. Fork the agrihealth repo on GitHub.

  2. Clone your fork locally:

    $ git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/agrihealth.git

  3. Install your local copy into a virtualenv. Assuming you have virtualenvwrapper installed, this is how you set up your fork for local development:

    $ mkvirtualenv agrihealth
$ cd agrihealth/
$ python setup.py develop

  4. Create a branch for local development:

    $ git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

    Now you can make your changes locally.

  5. When you're done making changes, check that your changes pass flake8 and the tests, including testing other Python versions with tox:

    $ flake8 agrihealth tests
$ python setup.py test or pytest
$ tox

    To get flake8 and tox, just pip install them into your virtualenv.

  6. Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:

    $ git add .
$ git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
$ git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

  7. Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

  1. The pull request should include tests.
  2. If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.rst.
  3. The pull request should work for Python 3.8 and later, and for PyPy. Check https://github.com/terra-geo/agrihealth/pull_requests and make sure that the tests pass for all supported Python versions.

docs.title: Stable release
docs.text:
To install agrihealth, run this command in your terminal:

pip install agrihealth

This is the preferred method to install agrihealth, as it will always install the most recent stable release.

If you don't have pip installed, this Python installation guide can guide you through the process.

docs.title: From sources
docs.text:
To install agrihealth from sources, run this command in your terminal:

pip install git+https://github.com/terra-geo/agrihealth

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
To use agrihealth in a project:

import agrihealth

docs.title: Crops
docs.text:
In [1]: Copied! 
import agrihealth
import agrihealth In [2]: Copied! 
from agrihealth.common import hello_world
from agrihealth.common import hello_world In [3]: Copied! 
hello_world()
hello_world() 
Hello World!
